title: Eco Design support in the Rhône-Alpes
segmentation: So good morning or hello, should I say now everybody?
I'm a shallow tricks.
Nicolas Mama, project manager in audio and helps.
And I'm pleased to see so many of you, and I also have to say I'm pleased to see that Arrow.
So many women here, because in France, Eco design is often a matter of men.
We see a lot of designers coming and a lot of engineers coming, and there aren't so many women.
So I'm pleased to see all the women here.
So I'm going to.
How do I go?
OK, first I want to tell you a few words about audio naps, just to situate who we are and what we're working on.
So I do and helps its original agency for development and innovation.

We were created on the 1st of January 2008 and it was a merger of seven existing agencies and we have founded and financed by the regional government of the Rhone AB region and also by the French Ministry of Industry, and our Commission is to contribute to the Sustainable economic development and competitiveness.
Of the Rona companies, when it comes to innovation, so we support the companies, especially the SMS in our region in innovation projects.
We are around the 70 employees and our Commission or no.

Sorry, I would remain activities are business intelligence, engineering of innovation, product projects and also networking of regional stakeholders which means that actually our main activity is to help the SMS in our region to do innovation projects and also to work together to do collaborative projects and that could be within ecodesign of course but also in many other.
Activities as you see, our main competence is our design materials artists, ICT performance, health, economic, electronic systems, networking, an regional innovation policies.

Pitched out so before being Rd in the design Department of D was actually an independent organization which was called Sandra Designer and help and we were created in 91 so we had a lot of years behind us and we already started to explore Eco design and sustainability in 2002 and we started just very simply to watch keep to participate in seminars and specially in the Scandinavian countries.

Which did quite a lot of work on sustainability at that time, and because our main idea was that the industrial designers had have an important role to play when designing new products with a better respect of the environment.
Because actually within the designers, Centreon helps.
Our main activities was to help companies who wanted to do new product projects and products with the designers.
So we thought that there was maybe something to do with the designers and the environment.

So in 2003 we did our first study to measure the implication of the companies with regards to sustainability and and they could design in the runup region and we found even though if France is not very advanced with respect to the environment and especially at that moment that actually some companies and some SMS has started to look at the environment and they could design and how to do better products, how to have less waste and how to respect the environment.

So we also started to have discussions with designers to measure their willingness to implicate themselves in a in a work of more respect to the environment when they were designing new products, and so actually most of the designers told us that what they learned when they went to design schools was actually to do better with less.
So it was kind of already in their genes to work on the environment and to work on.
They could design so it wasn't so difficult to convince them to try to do something.
More about it and based on those facts that this companies were starting to look at their code design and designers was willing to work on it.

We did a taste contract with a PhD student who was an environmental engineer and a designer and the idea was to develop a methodology especially for designers to integrate their respective the environment when designing new products.
Because what we also found when we started our watchkeeping was that most of the methodology's that exist us was actually.

It made for engineers and quite difficult to to use for designers because it was not about calculating environmental impact and everything, so it wasn't really adapted through the work of the designers in their everyday work.
So this PhD student started to work with us in 2000.
And full, which also was kind of the time where we started to be more organized about our activities and more focused on our activities in a quick design.
So since 2004 we did six ecodesign conferences with companies and designer experiences with expert lessons and workshops.
We have.

Some of them were quite international with the international speakers and other of them were really French and between French people we have also published several documents and articles on ecodesign.

And do we have been developing specially for designers training sessions, one which is specially called the four Tuesdays of Eco designed where we have tried to introduce the designers to some of the engineering methodology's but trying to translate them into more practical work but also to with creative sessions who have them work together to see how we could develop better products.
And we also have done some seminars.
Good design for executers that it was kind of kind of the other way around, meaning that we were trying to teach execute is how they should involve this sign in their work on environmental products.
And we have been able thanks to the PhD to student in particular to offer Eco design expertise to companies and designers on special projects that they had in mind.
Or they have started in their companies.
And as I will talk to you afterwards, we have developed two group actions for companies integrating design and respect for the environment which is see to see design and Eco Booster.
We have also did done a lot of lessons in schools and for designers.
An eco design more kind of to raise awareness of ecodesign already in in the design schools and which is not on the slide but which I have to mention.
We and our partner in the CTC network, the European project that my Anna told about in the introduction.

So if we now have a closer look on the seat to see design, which was the first collective action that we organized in 2006 and 2007, it was a collective action for group of companies and it was to allow them to experiment the secrecy approach because we got in touch with the people from APR in 2000, five 2006 and we found that the see to see approach was actually quite interesting also because.

The approach talk a lot about this design and how to end the role of designers within the integration of C to see, so we thought that there might be something to do and the DM was it with this collective action was to inform the companies about the secrecy concept and to facilitate the implementation of the philosophy in the companies.
But it was also at the same time to help the companies to work with designer on a real product development while experiencing.

Experimenting to see to see philosophy as external resources, we had the help of a peer to to organize this project that this was quite important for us because we didn't have the necessarily expertise to to teach the seat to see approach and we also had the help of five experts in different domains with regards to the questions that the different companies had with this within this group action.
We had to change of having a quite important financial support from the regional government, which means that the participation of the regionalism is was free of charge.

Whereas if he had to be paid for by other companies originally, the action was meant only for our regional companies, but we actually had interest from old, so big companies coming from other regions.
So as the group was not complete, we allowed them to participate in all.
All in all, we had nine companies from different industries to participate with the sport, equipment, promotional items, garden products, building equipment and automotive equipment.
And it is important to mention that there were no competitors in the group because we had quite a lot of work together with the companies.
And in order to have them.
To talk more freely, we found it quite important that we're nowhere competitors in the group.

So here you see the timeline for the project 2006 we used to to prepare the the action and also to recruit the companies and I have to say that even if it was free of charge for the SMS and it wasn't that easy to to convince the companies to participate because secrecy was really new and it still is in France, it was quite difficult to understand at the same time they needed to.
True to participate in quite a lot of work, so it wasn't that easy anyway.

We managed to have the nine companies and in the on the 1st of February 2007 the the action was officially launched with the Awareness Racing Day on the secrecy concept by EPF and this day was also the occasion to select the company projects and to brainstorm on different eco design ideas.

Then during February and April the companies started to prepare their projects and also to conclude the contracts with the designers because it was one of the conditions to participate in the in the action.
It was that there was a designer implicated.
It could be an internal designer already working in the company, but there should be a designer that was the condition.

And in April there was a individual work sessions in all of the companies supported by the Sun to design and thereby pier, and the idea was to finally define and start up the projects in each of the companies and then between April and June there was information exchanges between partners and also suppliers in order to get the information and data collection and materials and toxicity.

And there was the final project construction and then I peer provided individual support to all the companies and specially when calculating the toxicity of the materials which was used in the individual projects.
And then in June we had some time to Matic workshops with experts and I'll show you the themes afterwards.
And there was also a feedback meeting concerning the projects in each company.

In order for the company also to share their experiences and then the whole action was was followed by a group of researchers who looked at what's happened in the companies and how they work together with the designers and those researchers.
Chose at that moment the subjects for their articles.
And then finally, in Autumn 2007 we had our ecodesign conference.
And then we did a panel discussion where the company had the occasion to to give their experience feedback on the action.
So just to show you some of the themes that were treated by the experts and did was seems that came up during the discussion.
So between the central design and the companies or between appear and the companies when working on their projects.
For example, there were questions on materials, lifecycle on product, service approach on perceived value of equity sign project which is also quite important to treat becausw.
I don't know how it is in your countries, but in France.
At that moment, at least many people, consumers, and companies thought that it could.
Design products were poorer than the normal products, so it was quite important to work on the perceived value and also on the perceived value at the end of life components.

Which means that when the product is out of life you have to re use it if you want to applicate the secrecy approach and some of the companies thought that the components at the end of life were poor, so we needed to work on the perceived value of these.
Components and then there were questions on recyclability and environmental evaluation.
As one of the important questions in our group action was to integrate the design and the designers, is this environmental approach.
We had some conclusions of what could designers bring into this action, which engineers for example couldn't do as good as the designers.

So we found out that the designers, well, we concluded because it wasn't kind of a big revelation either, but that the designers were able to do a better definition of scenarios and product life cycles.

And also that the product promotion with an end of life perspective was easier when it was sold from the beginning and the designers also had a very important reflection on materials and toxicity from the beginning trying to integrate all those different aspects without necessarily an engineering approach and which is very important for the designers.
Integration of user expectations and experiences and which have to be done.
If you want to have the optimal.
Response to the product afterwards.
And we also think that designers have a positive and innovative approach to product development in all, and they were very able to translate.
Translate this into this product development with respect to the environment.
As for the results of those, this group action, it's actually quite difficult to tell because we had those nine companies participating.

And As for today I have the proof that only one company did the whole way through and actually developed product and The thing is that it's a product which is meant to last 30 years, so he at the moment being they don't really have the experience of what will they do at the end of life.
But As for the other companies.
The feedback that we have was that the C2C approach was really difficult for them to translate into operational actions, which is why we organized.
Afterwards, the Eco booster collective action.
It was actually kind of trying to respond to those difficulties of the operational aspects of the sea to see approach.
We decided to propose this action, which was based on the methodology which was developed by our PhD student.
GAIL give you an which is also a close loop methodology, but it's difficult and at the same time inspired by the sea to see.
So it was also a collective action for companies and the aim was to help the companies to to.

And hate their knowledge on there could design and to integrate environmental objects in product service development and also to think about a new pro speed based on a new business model which is service versus products, which means that you're not necessary in now are buying a new product, but more like a service an when you have used the product you give it back so you just have the service provided by the product.
And then finally, to initiate and support the concrete projects.
Projects of new product and service development.
Here we had our resources more internally as we had our PhD student and then we also integrated several experts.
We had the financial support from the original government again, but we decided to ask participation fee from the companies and then as participant.
I guess perhaps off the participation fee as well.
We had seven companies this time from different industries and also here we had no competitors.
I should see her again.

The product, the timeline where we used 2008 for preparation and recruitment of the companies and then actually was kind of the same machine with individual meetings with the companies and then collective workshops on on different themes and then again individual support to each companies with experts and with the people from Rd and then feedback meetings at the end.
Here you just have quickly the themes of that magic workshops which took place between February and March, and each theme was presented by an expert and just for the 4th.
The creative workshop here.
There each designer working on the project with the company, had the location to present their project and to have the feedback from the other companies participating.
And I also just show you quickly the main points of the methodology, which is which has been developed by GAIL Q.
And if some of you are interested in knowing more about this methodology, I can give you his email address and you can get in contact with him very easily.
And I think he would be very kind to to explain and to share with you the methodology's.
But actually the his idea of the.

Of the environment, environmental approach was to 1st observe the context of the company, then to structure the observed actions in short medium and long term, then to define the strategy strategy and objectives by integrating the actions and then to create alternative solutions within creative workshops, implicating a maximum of people in each company and also to integrate the designers.

So I think mostly because of those two, those two actions that we did and the relation that we have with the with a peer in for the first group action we got in contact with people from Limburg and they invited us to participate in the CTC Network.
And so we have been a partner in this checked since the beginning and one of the things which is very important for us within this European project is to create our own regional network.
Because of course it is important to share with the other partners and also to learn from the other partners, especially the good practices.
But it's also important for us to translate them into our own region and especially to translation into operational terms.

So we have constituted a network for companies, institutional bodies, organization and regional stakeholders and we have now organized several workshops where we try to translate the secrecy approach into something operational.

Where we kind of do the translation between cheese to see an echo design, and we we show them how to work in their companies with those concepts, and the idea is also to put people together and have them talk together and have them share experiences.
And also sometimes one carbon is working on one project and the other company could actually have some input on on these projects.
So this is the idea with with our network and also within the C to C project.
We have a lot of good practices and in.
J Chiefs and we tried to transfer them to our regional stakeholders.
So I guess that's it.
Thank you.
